docs.snippet: Always Be Prepared      ''I went to Omaha a few weeks before we started shooting, for a costume fitting,'' Kathy Bates said, describing her first day on the set of ''About Schmidt,'' Alexander Payne's film about a Nebraska businessman, played by J...
docs.lead_paragraph: Always Be Prepared ''I went to Omaha a few weeks before we started shooting, for a costume fitting,'' Kathy Bates said, describing her first day on the set of ''About Schmidt,'' Alexander Payne's film about a Nebraska businessman, played by Jack Nicholson, who must reinvent his life when his wife dies shortly after his retirement. ''Jack was there, and I got to see him, but mainly I got to travel around Omaha with Alexander. He's very proud of Omaha. He showed me where he grew up.''
docs.abstract: At the Movies column; Kathy Bates describes preparations for role in About Schmidt; photo; Christopher Plummer comments on playing title role in Nicholas Nickleby; Jerry Bruckheimer comments on making children's film Kangaroo Jack (S)

docs.snippet: Two 'Chicagos' Are Interacting      So has ''Chicago'' helped ''Chicago''? And how about Chicago, for that matter?    The first ''Chicago,'' of course, is that warhorse of a musical revival still running at the Shubert Theater on West 44th Street ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Two 'Chicagos' Are Interacting So has ''Chicago'' helped ''Chicago''? And how about Chicago, for that matter? The first ''Chicago,'' of course, is that warhorse of a musical revival still running at the Shubert Theater on West 44th Street and about to jump to the smaller Ambassador Theater at the end of the month. The second ''Chicago'' is the movie, in limited release until Feb. 7, which has been wowing critics and audiences and is being posited as an Oscar front-runner. The third Chicago is Chicago, that city by Lake Michigan where Cubs fans suffer.
docs.abstract: On Stage and Off column; speculation noted about whether new movie version of Chicago will help maintain Broadway musical version, which is moving to smaller Ambassador Theater after more than six years at Shubert; director Matthew Bourne leaves Disney production of The Little Mermaid; nominations for Britain's Laurence Olivier Awards include Gwyneth Paltrow for Proof; Baby June in revival of Gypsy will be Heather Tepe, 10-year-old non-Equity performer whose mother drove her from Little Falls, New Jersey, to open audition; photo (M)

docs.snippet: About a Boy      Actually, it's about two boys who help each other grow up. Marcus (Nicholas Hoult, left, with Hugh Grant), 12, has problems at school and at home with his self-pitying hippie mother (Toni Collette). Will (Mr. Grant), 38, does noth...
docs.lead_paragraph: About a Boy Actually, it's about two boys who help each other grow up. Marcus (Nicholas Hoult, left, with Hugh Grant), 12, has problems at school and at home with his self-pitying hippie mother (Toni Collette). Will (Mr. Grant), 38, does nothing but chase single mothers and avoid the responsibility of meaning anything to anyone.
docs.abstract: Brief reviews of films now released on video: About a Boy, Tadpole and Undercover Brother; photo (S)

docs.snippet: WORTHMAN-Martin. Died January 9, 2003, age 85, of New York and Ft. Lauderdale. Beloved husband of Ruth (Isaac) Worthman, devoted father of Roy and wife Laurie, and Douglas and wife Patricia. Loving brother of Della Weinberger & brotherin-law Oscar...
docs.lead_paragraph: WORTHMAN-Martin. Died January 9, 2003, age 85, of New York and Ft. Lauderdale. Beloved husband of Ruth (Isaac) Worthman, devoted father of Roy and wife Laurie, and Douglas and wife Patricia. Loving brother of Della Weinberger & brotherin-law Oscar, dear grandfather of Michael, Caleb, Alana and Nikki. Private graveside services: at New Montefiore Cemetery, Friday 1 P.M.

docs.snippet: WHEN the answering machine picks up at Creative Visions, callers are reminded that this skinny, brick-walled shop, a favorite with Hudson Street dogs because of its free biscuit policy, is now New York's only bookstore devoted to servicing the lit...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN the answering machine picks up at Creative Visions, callers are reminded that this skinny, brick-walled shop, a favorite with Hudson Street dogs because of its free biscuit policy, is now New York's only bookstore devoted to servicing the literary, and video, needs of the city's gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender community. But the answering machine doesn't pick up that often: this place always seems to be open, and according to its optimistic owner, Vincent Migliore, it is not doomed to obsolescence by the mainstreaming of its special-interest clientele, whose interests are finding shelf space and discounts at leviathans like Barnes & Noble and Amazon.com. Nor does it take responsibility for killing its more famous competition.
docs.abstract: Public Lives profile of Vincent Migliore, owner of Creative Visions, New York bookstore devoted to serving gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender community; photo (M)

headline.main: Advice From the Last Gay Bookstore: Read On

docs.snippet: WHEN Alyssa Shelasky, 26, was apartment-hunting earlier this month on West 78th Street near West End Avenue, the owner of a property she didn't find especially captivating shared some news he thought would help seal the deal.    ''He said, 'Britne...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Alyssa Shelasky, 26, was apartment-hunting earlier this month on West 78th Street near West End Avenue, the owner of a property she didn't find especially captivating shared some news he thought would help seal the deal. ''He said, 'Britney Spears is buying the brownstone two blocks down,' '' she said, ''like that was supposed to make up for the fact that it was a fifth-floor, 400-square-foot one-bedroom walk-up renting for $2,500 a month.''
docs.abstract: Value of New York City apartment can increase if celebrity lives nearby, preferably in same building; tradeoff is sometimes having paparazzi camped outside waiting for sightings; value is assessed neighborhood by neighborhood and some areas seem to be overrun with big names; photos (M)

headline.main: There Goes The Nabe: Up, Up, Up

docs.snippet: ''Bigger is better'' has been the mantra of more than one theater impresario. What you don't hear too often is ''smaller might be cool,'' and this is especially so if you're talking about musical revivals. But if the production of ''South Pacific'...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Bigger is better'' has been the mantra of more than one theater impresario. What you don't hear too often is ''smaller might be cool,'' and this is especially so if you're talking about musical revivals. But if the production of ''South Pacific'' by the Arena Stage here has any influence -- and it should -- the musical in miniature could well become a theatrical trend. Directed by Molly Smith, the show is the theatrical equivalent of stuffing a 10-pound weight into a 5-pound bag. Perhaps that sounds ill-advised. But with her revival of the mammoth drama ''The Great White Hope'' two seasons ago, Ms. Smith, this company's artistic director, effectively proved her flair for mounting ambitious, large-scale shows in the Arena's compact main auditorium.
docs.abstract: Bruce Weber reviews Arena Stage production of Rodgers and Hammerstein musical South Pacific, directed by Molly Smith; photo (M)

headline.main: Enchanted Across a Crowded (and Compact) Room

docs.snippet: Sir Anthony Havelock-Allan, a British film producer and scriptwriter who worked on major British films of the 1940's like ''Brief Encounter'' and ''Great Expectations,'' died on Jan. 11 in London. He was 98 and had made his home in London.    Sir ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Sir Anthony Havelock-Allan, a British film producer and scriptwriter who worked on major British films of the 1940's like ''Brief Encounter'' and ''Great Expectations,'' died on Jan. 11 in London. He was 98 and had made his home in London. Sir Anthony inherited the title of baronet in 1975.
docs.abstract: Sir Anthony Havelock-Allan, British film producer and scriptwriter, dies at age 98 (M)
